content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: 10 Lines for a puzzle seem reasonneable to me. The CRC definition is a + to me, it was fun to do !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i read it and found statement bit long  but clear.
Example was clear also.
I can code my own  non optimize solution in correct time without encountering any issue. 
So 5 min or size of code reach with optimize thinking.
I consider that can be a good challenge.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because the author implements a very good idea in this contribution.
Is it really a CRC (like using a polynom) ? Example given in the  "Enoncé" seems to be rather a mere checksum
Seems good for Shortest and also Fastest mode

1. Please move the hints from the Output section to the Goal section.

2. As per contribution guidelines, "CoC statements should be self-sufficient. When your time is counted, as a player, you don't want to waste time searching for a formula or a definition online to understand what needs to be done."
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines
Hence, please explain more and illustrate with an example in the Goal section.

It is technically a checksum, but it is what the title claims, the simplest CRC, 1-bit added to the end (parity bit), with polynomial (x+1) across 2 dimensions. An even simpler form is the xor8 (or longitudinal redundancy check), that adds a parity bit at the end of each 8bit word. They all belong in the greater family of Hamming codes. Maybe I should change the title to that? I felt like adding complexity with a more advanced CRC is unnecessary and defeats the purpose of the CoC.
